member.name: T:Csla.Wpf.ObjectStatus
member.summary: Container for other UI controls that exposes various status values from the CSLA .NET business object acting as DataContext.
member.remarks: This control provides access to the IsDirty, IsNew, IsDeleted, IsValid and IsSavable properties of a business object. The purpose behind this control is to expose those properties in a way that supports WFP data binding against those values.

member.summary: Creates an instance of the object.

member.name: T:Csla.Windows.HostComponentDesigner
member.summary: HostComponentDesigner is an enhanced ComponentDesigner class used for linking a parent container control to a component marked with the HostComponentDesigner attribute as a .NET designer service.

member.name: M:Csla.Windows.HostComponentDesigner.InitializeNewComponent(System.Collections.IDictionary)
member.summary: InitializeNewComponent() overrides the base class InitializeNewComponent() method. This version of InitializeNewComponent() simply runs through the base class InitializeNewComponent functionality then if the associated component contains the HostPropertyAttribute attribute the conponent's host property is then set to the parent component if the component is a container control.
member.param: The default values for initialising the new component.

member.name: M:Csla.Validation.ValidationRules.GetRuleDescriptions
member.summary: Returns an array containing the text descriptions of all validation rules associated with this object.

member.name: M:Csla.Validation.ValidationRules.AddInstanceRule(Csla.Validation.RuleHandler,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a rule to the list of rules to be enforced.

remarks.para: A rule is implemented by a method which conforms to the method signature defined by the RuleHandler delegate.

The propertyName may be used by the method that implements the rule in order to retrieve the value to be validated. If the rule implementation is inside the target object then it probably has direct access to all data. However, if the rule implementation is outside the target object then it will need to use reflection or CallByName to dynamically invoke this property to retrieve the value to be validated.

member.param: The method that implements the rule.
The property name on the target object where the rule implementation can retrieve the value to be validated.

member.name: M:Csla.Validation.ValidationRules.AddInstanceRule(Csla.Validation.RuleHandler,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds a rule to the list of rules to be enforced.

remarks.para: A rule is implemented by a method which conforms to the method signature defined by the RuleHandler delegate.

The propertyName may be used by the method that implements the rule in order to retrieve the value to be validated. If the rule implementation is inside the target object then it probably has direct access to all data. However, if the rule implementation is outside the target object then it will need to use reflection or CallByName to dynamically invoke this property to retrieve the value to be validated.

member.param: The method that implements the rule.
The property name on the target object where the rule implementation can retrieve the value to be validated.
The priority of the rule, where lower numbers are processed first.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ISequenced`1
member.summary:
An editable collection maintaining a definite sequence order of the items.
Implementations of this interface must compute the hash code and equality exactly as prescribed in the method definitions in order to be consistent with other collection classes implementing this interface. This interface is usually implemented by explicit interface implementation, not as ordinary virtual methods.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ICollectionValue`1
member.summary: A generic collection that may be enumerated and can answer efficiently how many items it contains. Like IEnumerable<T>, this interface does not prescribe any operations to initialize or update the collection. The main usage for this interface is to be the return type of query operations on generic collection.

Choose some item of this collection.

member.summary: Add an item to this collection if possible. If this collection has set semantics, the item will be added if not already in the collection. If bag semantics, the item will always be added.

member.summary: Copy the items of this collection to a contiguous part of an array.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ICollection`1.GetUnsequencedHashCode
member.summary:
The unordered collection hashcode is defined as the sum of h(hashcode(item)) over the items of the collection, where the function h is a function from int to int of the form t -> (a0*t+b0)^(a1*t+b1)^(a2*t+b2), where the ax and bx are the same for all collection classes.
The current implementation uses fixed values for the ax and bx, specified as constants in the code.
member.returns: The unordered hashcode of this collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ICollection`1.UnsequencedEquals(Csla.C5.ICollection{`0})
member.summary: Compare the contents of this collection to another one without regards to the sequence order. The comparison will use this collection's itemequalityComparer to compare individual items.
member.returns: True if this collection and that contains the same items.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ICollection`1.Contains(`0)
member.summary: Check if this collection contains (an item equivalent to according to the itemequalityComparer) a particular value.
member.returns: True if the items is in this collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ICollection`1.ContainsCount(`0)
member.summary: Count the number of items of the collection equal to a particular value. Returns 0 if and only if the value is not in the collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ICollection`1.ContainsAll``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Check whether this collection contains all the values in another collection. If this collection has bag semantics (AllowsDuplicates==true) the check is made with respect to multiplicities, else multiplicities are not taken into account.
member.returns: True if all values in itemsis in this collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ICollection`1.Find(`0@)
member.summary: Check if this collection contains an item equivalent according to the itemequalityComparer to a particular value. If so, return in the ref argument (a binary copy of) the actual value found.
member.returns: True if the items is in this collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ICollection`1.FindOrAdd(`0@)
member.summary: Check if this collection contains an item equivalent according to the itemequalityComparer to a particular value. If so, return in the ref argument (a binary copy of) the actual value found. Else, add the item to the collection.
member.returns: True if the item was found (hence not added).

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ICollection`1.Update(`0)
member.summary: Check if this collection contains an item equivalent according to the itemequalityComparer to a particular value. If so, update the item in the collection with a (binary copy of) the supplied value. If the collection has bag semantics, it depends on the value of DuplicatesByCounting if this updates all equivalent copies in the collection or just one.
member.returns: True if the item was found and hence updated.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ICollection`1.Update(`0,`0@)
member.summary: Check if this collection contains an item equivalent according to the itemequalityComparer to a particular value. If so, update the item in the collection with a (binary copy of) the supplied value. If the collection has bag semantics, it depends on the value of DuplicatesByCounting if this updates all equivalent copies in the collection or just one.
member.param: On output the olditem, if found.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ArrayList`1
member.summary:
A list collection based on a plain dynamic array data structure. Expansion of the internal array is performed by doubling on demand. The internal array is only shrinked by the Clear method.
When the FIFO property is set to false this class works fine as a stack of T. When the FIFO property is set to true the class will function as a (FIFO) queue but very inefficiently, use a LinkedList () instead.

member.name: M:Csla.Validation.BrokenRulesCollection.Merge(System.String,Csla.Validation.BrokenRulesCollection)
member.summary: Merges data from the supplied list into this list, changing the rule names to be unique based on the source value.
member.param: A unique source name for each list being merged into this master list.
A list to merge into this master list.
member.remarks: This method is intended to allow merging of all BrokenRulesCollection objects in a business object graph into a single list. To this end, no attempt is made to remove duplicates during the merge process. Also, the source parameter value must be unqiue for each object instance in the graph, or rule name collisions may occur.

member.summary: Serialize an object graph into DTO.
member.param: Root object of the object graph to serialize.

summary.para: Converts any enum values in the objects to integer representations. Normally, requires all non-standard primitive types to be provided to it's constructor both upon serialization and deserialization. Since there is no way of knowing what enum values are being deserialized, there is no way to supply the types to the constructor at the time of deserialization.
Instead we convert the enum values to integers prior to serialization and then back to proper enum objects after deserialization.

member.name: T:Csla.Validation.AsyncValidationRuleContext
member.summary: Provides context information to an asynchronous validation rule.

member.name: M:Csla.Validation.AsyncValidationRuleContext.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Object},Csla.Validation.AsyncRuleArgs,Csla.Validation.AsyncRuleResult,Csla.Validation.AsyncRuleResultHandler)
member.summary: Creates an instance of the object.
member.param: Dictionary containing copies of the business object property values for the properties associated with this rule.
Input arguments for use by the rule method.
Default output arguments that can be changed by the rule method.
Async result handler for the async callback on completion of the rule.

member.name: M:Csla.Validation.AsyncValidationRuleContext.Complete
member.summary: Method that notifies the validation subsystem when the async rule method is complete. This method must be called!
member.remarks: The async rule method must call this Complete() method when it is done (successfully or unsuccessfully). This includes the case where an exception occurred in the rule method. This method must be called no matter what happens.

member.name: P:Csla.Validation.AsyncValidationRuleContext.PropertyValues
member.summary: Gets a Dictionary containing the values of all properties associated with this rule.
member.remarks: The values provided by this property are copies of the original values. This helps provide thread safety, allowing a rule method to interact with the values safely, even though the code is running on a background thread.

member.name: P:Csla.Validation.AsyncValidationRuleContext.InArgs
member.summary: Gets the input arguments to the validation rule.
member.remarks: This property provides much of the same information as the RuleArgs parameter does to a synchronous rule method.

member.name: P:Csla.Validation.AsyncValidationRuleContext.OutArgs
member.summary: Gets the output arguments for the validation rule. The rule should set properties on this object for return to the validation subsystem.

member.name: F:Csla.TransactionalTypes.TransactionScope

member.remarks: This option allows the business developer to implement their own transactions. Common options include ADO.NET transactions and System.Transactions TransactionScope.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.HashedArrayList`1
member.summary:
A list collection based on a plain dynamic array data structure. Expansion of the internal array is performed by doubling on demand. The internal array is only shrinked by the Clear method.
When the FIFO property is set to false this class works fine as a stack of T. When the FIFO property is set to true the class will function as a (FIFO) queue but very inefficiently, use a LinkedList () instead.

member.summary: Creates an instance of RuleArgs.
member.param: The name of the property to be validated.
Initial default severity for the rule.

remarks.para: The severity parameter defines only the initial default severity value. If the rule changes this value by setting e.Severity, then that new value will become the default for all subsequent rule invocations.
To avoid confusion, it is recommended that the severity constructor parameter only be used for rule methods that do not explicitly set e.Severity.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.IntervalHeap`1
member.summary: A priority queue class based on an interval heap data structure.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1
member.summary:
A generic collection of items prioritized by a comparison (order) relation. Supports adding items and reporting or removing extremal elements.
When adding an item, the user may choose to have a handle allocated for this item in the queue. The resulting handle may be used for deleting the item even if not extremal, and for replacing the item. A priority queue typically only holds numeric priorities associated with some objects maintained separately in other collection objects.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.FindMin
member.summary: Find the current least item of this priority queue.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.DeleteMin
member.summary: Remove the least item from this priority queue.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.FindMax
member.summary: Find the current largest item of this priority queue.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.DeleteMax
member.summary: Remove the largest item from this priority queue.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.Find(Csla.C5.IPriorityQueueHandle{`0},`0@)
member.summary: Check if the entry corresponding to a handle is in the priority queue.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.Add(Csla.C5.IPriorityQueueHandle{`0}@,`0)
member.summary: Add an item to the priority queue, receiving a handle for the item in the queue, or reusing an existing unused handle.
member.param: On output: a handle for the added item. On input: null for allocating a new handle, or a currently unused handle for reuse. A handle for reuse must be compatible with this priority queue, by being created by a priority queue of the same runtime type, but not necessarily the same priority queue object.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.Delete(Csla.C5.IPriorityQueueHandle{`0})
member.summary: Delete an item with a handle from a priority queue
member.param: The handle for the item. The handle will be invalidated, but reusable.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.Replace(Csla.C5.IPriorityQueueHandle{`0},`0)
member.summary: Replace an item with a handle in a priority queue with a new item. Typically used for changing the priority of some queued object.
member.param: The handle for the old item

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.FindMin(Csla.C5.IPriorityQueueHandle{`0}@)
member.summary: Find the current least item of this priority queue.
member.param: On return: the handle of the item.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.FindMax(Csla.C5.IPriorityQueueHandle{`0}@)
member.summary: Find the current largest item of this priority queue.
member.param: On return: the handle of the item.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.DeleteMin(Csla.C5.IPriorityQueueHandle{`0}@)
member.summary: Remove the least item from this priority queue.
member.param: On return: the handle of the removed item.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IPriorityQueue`1.DeleteMax(Csla.C5.IPriorityQueueHandle{`0}@)
member.summary: Remove the largest item from this priority queue.
member.param: On return: the handle of the removed item.

member.summary: The comparer object supplied at creation time for this collection
member.value: The comparer

member.name: M:Csla.C5.IntervalHeap`1.Add(Csla.C5.IPriorityQueueHandle{`0}@,`0)
member.summary: Add an item to the priority queue, receiving a handle for the item in the queue, or reusing an already existing handle.
member.param: On output: a handle for the added item. On input: null for allocating a new handle, an invalid handle for reuse. A handle for reuse must be compatible with this priority queue, by being created by a priority queue of the same runtime type, but not necessarily the same priority queue object.
member.returns: True since item will always be added unless the call throws an exception.

member.name: T:Csla.Core.ITrackStatus
member.summary: Defines the common properties required objects that track their own status.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.ITrackStatus.IsValid
member.summary: Returns if the object and its child objects are currently valid, if the object or any of its child objects have broken rules or are otherwise invalid.

remarks.para: By default this property relies on the underling ValidationRules object to track whether any business rules are currently broken for this object.

You can override this property to provide more sophisticated implementations of the behavior. For instance, you should always override this method if your object has child objects, since the validity of this object is affected by the validity of all child objects.

member.returns: A value indicating if the object is currently valid.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.ITrackStatus.IsSelfValid
member.summary: Returns if the object is currently valid, if the object has broken rules or is otherwise invalid.

remarks.para: By default this property relies on the underling ValidationRules object to track whether any business rules are currently broken for this object.
You can override this property to provide more sophisticated implementations of the behavior.

member.returns: A value indicating if the object is currently valid.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.ITrackStatus.IsDirty
member.summary: Returns if this object's data, or any of its fields or child objects data, has been changed.

remarks.para: When an object's data is changed, CSLA .NET makes note of that change and considers the object to be 'dirty' or changed. This value is used to optimize data updates, since an unchanged object does not need to be updated into the database. All new objects are considered dirty. All objects marked for deletion are considered dirty.

Once an object's data has been saved to the database (inserted or updated) the dirty flag is cleared and the object is considered unchanged. Objects newly loaded from the database are also considered unchanged.

member.returns: A value indicating if this object's data has been changed.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.ITrackStatus.IsSelfDirty
member.summary: Returns if this object's data has been changed.

remarks.para: When an object's data is changed, CSLA .NET makes note of that change and considers the object to be 'dirty' or changed. This value is used to optimize data updates, since an unchanged object does not need to be updated into the database. All new objects are considered dirty. All objects marked for deletion are considered dirty.

Once an object's data has been saved to the database (inserted or updated) the dirty flag is cleared and the object is considered unchanged. Objects newly loaded from the database are also considered unchanged.

member.returns: A value indicating if this object's data has been changed.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.ITrackStatus.IsDeleted
member.summary: Returns if this object is marked for deletion.
member.remarks: CSLA .NET supports both immediate and deferred deletion of objects. This property is part of the support for deferred deletion, where an object can be marked for deletion, but isn't actually deleted until the object is saved to the database. This property indicates whether or not the current object has been marked for deletion. If it is , the object will be deleted when it is saved to the database, otherwise it will be inserted or updated by the save operation.
member.returns: A value indicating if this object is marked for deletion.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.ITrackStatus.IsNew
member.summary: Returns if this is a new object, if it is a pre-existing object.
member.remarks: An object is considered to be new if its primary identifying (key) value doesn't correspond to data in the database. In other words, if the data values in this particular object have not yet been saved to the database the object is considered to be new. Likewise, if the object's data has been deleted from the database then the object is considered to be new.
member.returns: A value indicating if this object is new.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.ITrackStatus.IsSavable
member.summary: Returns if this object is both dirty and valid.
member.remarks: An object is considered dirty (changed) if returns . It is considered valid if IsValid returns . The IsSavable property is a combination of these two properties.
member.returns: A value indicating if this object is both dirty and valid.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ISorted`1
member.summary:
A sorted collection, i.e. a collection where items are maintained and can be searched for in sorted order. Thus the sequence order is given as a sorting order.
The sorting order is defined by a comparer, an object of type IComparer<T> (). Implementors of this interface will normally let the user define the comparer as an argument to a constructor. Usually there will also be constructors without a comparer argument, in which case the comparer should be the defalt comparer for the item type, .
The comparer of the sorted collection is available as the Comparer property ().
The methods are grouped according to
Extrema: report or report and delete an extremal item. This is reminiscent of simplified priority queues.
Nearest neighbor: report predecessor or successor in the collection of an item. Cut belongs to this group.
Range: report a view of a range of elements or remove all elements in a range.
AddSorted: add a collection of items known to be sorted in the same order (should be faster) (to be removed?)
Since this interface extends ISequenced<T>, sorted collections will also have an item equalityComparer (). This equalityComparer will not be used in connection with the inner workings of the sorted collection, but will be used if the sorted collection is used as an item in a collection of unsequenced or sequenced collections, ( and )
Note that code may check if two sorted collections has the same sorting order by checking if the Comparer properties are equal. This is done a few places in this library for optimization purposes.

member.summary: Find the current least item of this sorted collection.
member.exception: if the collection is empty.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ISorted`1.DeleteMin
member.summary: Remove the least item from this sorted collection.
member.exception: if the collection is empty.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ISorted`1.FindMax
member.summary: Find the current largest item of this sorted collection.
member.exception: if the collection is empty.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ISorted`1.DeleteMax

member.exception: if the collection is empty.

member.summary: Find the strict predecessor of item in the sorted collection, that is, the greatest item in the collection smaller than the item.
member.param: The item to find the predecessor for.
The predecessor, if any; otherwise the default value for T.
member.returns: True if item has a predecessor; otherwise false.

The successor, if any; otherwise the default value for T.
member.returns: True if item has a successor; otherwise false.

member.returns: True if item has a weak predecessor; otherwise false.

The weak successor, if any; otherwise the default value for T.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ISorted`1.Cut(System.IComparable{`0},`0@,System.Boolean@,`0@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary:
Given a "cut" function from the items of the sorted collection to int whose only sign changes when going through items in increasing order can be
from positive to zero
from positive to negative
from zero to negative
The "cut" function is supplied as the CompareTo method of an object c implementing IComparable<T>. A typical example is the case where T is comparable and cutFunction is itself of type T.
This method performs a search in the sorted collection for the ranges in which the "cut" function is negative, zero respectively positive. If T is comparable and c is of type T, this is a safe way (no exceptions thrown) to find predecessor and successor of c.
If the supplied cut function does not satisfy the sign-change condition, the result of this call is undefined.
member.param: The cut function T to int, given by the CompareTo method of an object implementing IComparable<T>.
Returns the largest item in the collection, where the cut function is positive (if any).
Returns true if the cut function is positive somewhere on this collection.
Returns the least item in the collection, where the cut function is negative (if any).
Returns true if the cut function is negative somewhere on this collection.
member.returns: True if the cut function is zero somewhere on this collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ISorted`1.RangeFrom(`0)
member.summary:
Query this sorted collection for items greater than or equal to a supplied value.
The returned collection is not a copy but a view into the collection.
The view is fragile in the sense that changes to the underlying collection will invalidate the view so that further operations on the view throws InvalidView exceptions.

member.summary:
Query this sorted collection for items between two supplied values.
The returned collection is not a copy but a view into the collection.
The view is fragile in the sense that changes to the underlying collection will invalidate the view so that further operations on the view throws InvalidView exceptions.

member.summary:
Query this sorted collection for items less than a supplied value.
The returned collection is not a copy but a view into the collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ISortedDictionary`2.Cut(System.IComparable{`0},Csla.C5.KeyValuePair{`0,`1}@,System.Boolean@,Csla.C5.KeyValuePair{`0,`1}@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary:
Given a "cut" function from the items of the sorted collection to int whose only sign changes when going through items in increasing order can be
from positive to zero
from positive to negative
from zero to negative
The "cut" function is supplied as the CompareTo method of an object c implementing IComparable<K>. A typical example is the case where K is comparable and c is itself of type K.
This method performs a search in the sorted collection for the ranges in which the "cut" function is negative, zero respectively positive. If K is comparable and c is of type K, this is a safe way (no exceptions thrown) to find predecessor and successor of c.
If the supplied cut function does not satisfy the sign-change condition, the result of this call is undefined.
member.param: The cut function K to int, given by the CompareTo method of an object implementing IComparable<K>.
Returns the largest item in the collection, where the cut function is positive (if any).
Returns true if the cut function is positive somewhere on this collection.
Returns the least item in the collection, where the cut function is negative (if any).
Returns true if the cut function is negative somewhere on this collection.
member.returns: True if the cut function is zero somewhere on this collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ISortedDictionary`2.RangeFrom(`0)
member.summary:
Query this sorted collection for items greater than or equal to a supplied value.
The returned collection is not a copy but a view into the collection.
The view is fragile in the sense that changes to the underlying collection will invalidate the view so that further operations on the view throws InvalidView exceptions.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ISortedDictionary`2.RangeFromTo(`0,`0)

The view is fragile in the sense that changes to the underlying collection will invalidate the view so that further operations on the view throws InvalidView exceptions.

member.name: M:Csla.DataPortal.Execute``1(``0)
member.summary: Called to execute a Command object on the server.

remarks.para: To be a Command object, the object must inherit from CommandBase.

Note that this method returns a reference to the updated business object. If the server-side DataPortal is running remotely, this will be a new and different object from the original, and all object references MUST be updated to use this new object.
On the server, the Command object's DataPortal_Execute() method will be invoked. Write any server-side code in that method.

member.typeparam: Specific type of the Command object.
member.param: A reference to the Command object to be executed.
member.returns: A reference to the updated Command object.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.TreeSet`1
member.summary:
An implementation of Red-Black trees as an indexed, sorted collection with set semantics, cf. CLRS. for a version with bag semantics. for a sorted dictionary based on this tree implementation.
The comparer (sorting order) may be either natural, because the item type is comparable (generic: or non-generic: System.IComparable) or it can be external and supplied by the user in the constructor.
TODO: describe performance here TODO: discuss persistence and its useful usage modes. Warn about the space leak possible with other usage modes.

member.summary: Create a red-black tree collection with natural comparer and item equalityComparer. We assume that if T is comparable, its default equalityComparer will be compatible with the comparer.
member.exception: If T is not comparable.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.SortedArray`1.Cut(System.IComparable{`0},`0@,System.Boolean@,`0@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Perform a search in the sorted collection for the ranges in which a non-increasing (i.e. weakly decrerasing) function from the item type to int is negative, zero respectively positive. If the supplied cut function is not non-increasing, the result of this call is undefined.
member.param: The cut function T to int, given as an IComparable<T> object, where the cut function is the c.CompareTo(T that) method.
Returns the largest item in the collection, where the cut function is positive (if any).
True if the cut function is positive somewhere on this collection.
Returns the least item in the collection, where the cut function is negative (if any).
True if the cut function is negative somewhere on this collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.SortedArray`1.FindOrAdd(`0@)
member.summary: Check if this collection contains an item equivalent according to the itemequalityComparer to a particular value. If so, return in the ref argument (a binary copy of) the actual value found. Else, add the item to the collection.
member.returns: True if the item was added (hence not found).

member.name: M:Csla.C5.SortedArray`1.Update(`0)
member.summary: Check if this collection contains an item equivalent according to the itemequalityComparer to a particular value. If so, update the item in the collection to with a binary copy of the supplied value. If the collection has bag semantics, it is implementation dependent if this updates all equivalent copies in the collection or just one.
member.returns: True if the item was found and hence updated.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.SortedArray`1.UpdateOrAdd(`0)
member.summary: Check if this collection contains an item equivalent according to the itemequalityComparer to a particular value. If so, update the item in the collection to with a binary copy of the supplied value; else add the value to the collection.
member.returns: True if the item was found and updated (hence not added).

member.summary: Remove a particular item from this collection. If the collection has bag semantics only one copy equivalent to the supplied item is removed.
member.returns: True if the item was found (and removed).

member.name: M:Csla.C5.SortedArray`1.Remove(`0,`0@)
member.summary: Remove a particular item from this collection if found. If the collection has bag semantics only one copy equivalent to the supplied item is removed, which one is implementation dependent. If an item was removed, report a binary copy of the actual item removed in the argument.
member.returns: True if the item was found (and removed).

Please refer to 'Expert C# 2008 Business Objects' for full details on the use of this base class to create business objects.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.MarkNew
member.summary: Marks the object as being a new object. This also marks the object as being dirty and ensures that it is not marked for deletion.

remarks.para: Newly created objects are marked new by default. You should call this method in the implementation of DataPortal_Update when the object is deleted (due to being marked for deletion) to indicate that the object no longer reflects data in the database.
If you override this method, make sure to call the base implementation after executing your new code.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.MarkOld
member.summary: Marks the object as being an old (not new) object. This also marks the object as being unchanged (not dirty).

remarks.para: You should call this method in the implementation of DataPortal_Fetch to indicate that an existing object has been successfully retrieved from the database.
You should call this method in the implementation of DataPortal_Update to indicate that a new object has been successfully inserted into the database.
If you override this method, make sure to call the base implementation after executing your new code.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.MarkDeleted
member.summary: Marks an object for deletion. This also marks the object as being dirty.
member.remarks: You should call this method in your business logic in the case that you want to have the object deleted when it is saved to the database.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.MarkDirty
member.summary: Marks an object as being dirty, or changed.

remarks.para: You should call this method in your business logic any time the object's internal data changes. Any time any instance variable changes within the object, this method should be called to tell CSLA .NET that the object's data has been changed.

Marking an object as dirty does two things. First it ensures that CSLA .NET will properly save the object as appropriate. Second, it causes CSLA .NET to tell Windows Forms data binding that the object's data has changed so any bound controls will update to reflect the new values.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.MarkDirty(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Marks an object as being dirty, or changed.
member.param: to supress the PropertyChanged event that is otherwise raised to indicate that the object's state has changed.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.PropertyHasChanged
member.summary: Performs processing required when the current property has changed.

remarks.para: This method calls CheckRules(propertyName), MarkDirty and OnPropertyChanged(propertyName). MarkDirty is called such that no event is raised for IsDirty, so only the specific property changed event for the current property is raised.
This implementation uses System.Diagnostics.StackTrace to determine the name of the current property, and so must be called directly from the property to be checked.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.PropertyHasChanged(System.String)
member.summary: Performs processing required when a property has changed.
member.param: Name of the property that has changed.
member.remarks: This method calls CheckRules(propertyName), MarkDirty and OnPropertyChanged(propertyName). MarkDirty is called such that no event is raised for IsDirty, so only the specific property changed event for the current property is raised.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.MarkClean
member.summary: Forces the object's IsDirty flag to .
member.remarks: This method is normally called automatically and is not intended to be called manually.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.CanReadProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Returns if the user is allowed to read the specified property.
member.param: Name of the property to read.

remarks.para: If a list of allowed roles is provided then only users in those roles can read. If no list of allowed roles is provided then the list of denied roles is checked.
If a list of denied roles is provided then users in the denied roles are denied read access. All other users are allowed.
If neither a list of allowed nor denied roles is provided then all users will have read access.

member.summary: Returns if the user is allowed to execute the specified method.
member.param: Name of the method to execute.

remarks.para: If a list of allowed roles is provided then only users in those roles can execute the method. If no list of allowed roles is provided then the list of denied roles is checked.
If a list of denied roles is provided then users in the denied roles are not allowed to execute the method. All other users are allowed.
If neither a list of allowed nor denied roles is provided then all users will be allowed to execute the method..

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.System#ComponentModel#IEditableObject#BeginEdit
member.summary: Allow data binding to start a nested edit on the object.
member.remarks: Data binding may call this method many times. Only the first call should be honored, so we have extra code to detect this and do nothing for subsquent calls.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.System#ComponentModel#IEditableObject#CancelEdit
member.summary: Allow data binding to cancel the current edit.
member.remarks: Data binding may call this method many times. Only the first call to either IEditableObject.CancelEdit or IEditableObject.EndEdit should be honored. We include extra code to detect this and do nothing for subsequent calls.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.System#ComponentModel#IEditableObject#EndEdit
member.summary: Allow data binding to apply the current edit.
member.remarks: Data binding may call this method many times. Only the first call to either IEditableObject.EndEdit or IEditableObject.CancelEdit should be honored. We include extra code to detect this and do nothing for subsequent calls.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.BeginEdit
member.summary: Starts a nested edit on the object.

remarks.para: When this method is called the object takes a snapshot of its current state (the values of its variables). This snapshot can be restored by calling CancelEdit or committed by calling ApplyEdit.

This is a nested operation. Each call to BeginEdit adds a new snapshot of the object's state to a stack. You should ensure that for each call to BeginEdit there is a corresponding call to either CancelEdit or ApplyEdit to remove that snapshot from the stack.
See Chapters 2 and 3 for details on n-level undo and state stacking.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.CancelEdit
member.summary: Cancels the current edit process, restoring the object's state to its previous values.
member.remarks: Calling this method causes the most recently taken snapshot of the object's state to be restored. This resets the object's values to the point of the last BeginEdit call.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.UndoChangesComplete
member.summary: Called when an undo operation has completed.
member.remarks: This method resets the object as a result of deserialization and raises PropertyChanged events to notify data binding that the object has changed.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.ApplyEdit
member.summary: Commits the current edit process.
member.remarks: Calling this method causes the most recently taken snapshot of the object's state to be discarded, thus committing any changes made to the object's state since the last BeginEdit call.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.AcceptChangesComplete
member.summary: Notifies the parent object (if any) that this child object's edits have been accepted.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.MarkAsChild
member.summary: Marks the object as being a child object.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.Delete
member.summary: Marks the object for deletion. The object will be deleted as part of the next save operation.

remarks.para: CSLA .NET supports both immediate and deferred deletion of objects. This method is part of the support for deferred deletion, where an object can be marked for deletion, but isn't actually deleted until the object is saved to the database. This method is called by the UI developer to mark the object for deletion.
To 'undelete' an object, use n-level undo as discussed in Chapters 2 and 3.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.DeleteChild
member.summary: Called by a parent object to mark the child for deferred deletion.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.IsNew
member.summary: Returns if this is a new object, if it is a pre-existing object.
member.remarks: An object is considered to be new if its primary identifying (key) value doesn't correspond to data in the database. In other words, if the data values in this particular object have not yet been saved to the database the object is considered to be new. Likewise, if the object's data has been deleted from the database then the object is considered to be new.
member.returns: A value indicating if this object is new.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.IsDeleted
member.summary: Returns if this object is marked for deletion.
member.remarks: CSLA .NET supports both immediate and deferred deletion of objects. This property is part of the support for deferred deletion, where an object can be marked for deletion, but isn't actually deleted until the object is saved to the database. This property indicates whether or not the current object has been marked for deletion. If it is , the object will be deleted when it is saved to the database, otherwise it will be inserted or updated by the save operation.
member.returns: A value indicating if this object is marked for deletion.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.IsDirty
member.summary: Returns if this object's data, or any of its fields or child objects data, has been changed.

remarks.para: When an object's data is changed, CSLA .NET makes note of that change and considers the object to be 'dirty' or changed. This value is used to optimize data updates, since an unchanged object does not need to be updated into the database. All new objects are considered dirty. All objects marked for deletion are considered dirty.

Once an object's data has been saved to the database (inserted or updated) the dirty flag is cleared and the object is considered unchanged. Objects newly loaded from the database are also considered unchanged.

member.returns: A value indicating if this object's data has been changed.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.IsSelfDirty
member.summary: Returns if this object's data has been changed.

remarks.para: When an object's data is changed, CSLA .NET makes note of that change and considers the object to be 'dirty' or changed. This value is used to optimize data updates, since an unchanged object does not need to be updated into the database. All new objects are considered dirty. All objects marked for deletion are considered dirty.

Once an object's data has been saved to the database (inserted or updated) the dirty flag is cleared and the object is considered unchanged. Objects newly loaded from the database are also considered unchanged.

member.returns: A value indicating if this object's data has been changed.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.IsSavable
member.summary: Returns if this object is both dirty and valid.
member.remarks: An object is considered dirty (changed) if returns . It is considered valid if IsValid returns . The IsSavable property is a combination of these two properties.
member.returns: A value indicating if this object is both dirty and valid.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.AuthorizationRules
member.summary: Provides access to the AuthorizationRules object for this object.
member.remarks: Use this object to add a list of allowed and denied roles for reading and writing properties of the object. Typically these values are added once when the business object is instantiated.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.Parent
member.summary: Provide access to the parent reference for use in child object code.
member.remarks: This value will be Nothing for root objects.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.DisableIEditableObject
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the IEditableObject interface methods should be disabled for this object.
member.value: Defaults to False, indicating that the IEditableObject methods will behave normally.
member.remarks: If you disable the IEditableObject methods then Windows Forms data binding will no longer automatically call BeginEdit, CancelEdit or ApplyEdit on your object, and you will have to call these methods manually to get proper n-level undo behavior.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.ValidationRules
member.summary: Provides access to the broken rules functionality.
member.remarks: This property is used within your business logic so you can easily call the AddRule() method to associate validation rules with your object's properties.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.IsValid
member.summary: Returns if the object and its child objects are currently valid, if the object or any of its child objects have broken rules or are otherwise invalid.

remarks.para: By default this property relies on the underling ValidationRules object to track whether any business rules are currently broken for this object.

You can override this property to provide more sophisticated implementations of the behavior. For instance, you should always override this method if your object has child objects, since the validity of this object is affected by the validity of all child objects.

member.returns: A value indicating if the object is currently valid.

member.name: P:Csla.Core.BusinessBase.IsSelfValid
member.summary: Returns if the object is currently valid, if the object has broken rules or is otherwise invalid.

remarks.para: By default this property relies on the underling ValidationRules object to track whether any business rules are currently broken for this object.
You can override this property to provide more sophisticated implementations of the behavior.

member.returns: A value indicating if the object is currently valid.

member.name: M:Csla.BusinessBase`1.Save
member.summary: Saves the object to the database.

remarks.para: Calling this method starts the save operation, causing the object to be inserted, updated or deleted within the database based on the object's current state.
If is the object will be deleted. Otherwise, if is the object will be inserted. Otherwise the object's data will be updated in the database.

All this is contingent on . If this value is , no data operation occurs. It is also contingent on . If this value is an exception will be thrown to indicate that the UI attempted to save an invalid object.

It is important to note that this method returns a new version of the business object that contains any data updated during the save operation. You MUST update all object references to use this new version of the business object in order to have access to the correct object data.

You can override this method to add your own custom behaviors to the save operation. For instance, you may add some security checks to make sure the user can save the object. If all security checks pass, you would then invoke the base Save method via base.Save().

member.returns: A new object containing the saved values.

member.name: M:Csla.BusinessBase`1.Save(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Saves the object to the database, forcing IsNew to and IsDirty to True.
member.param: If , triggers overriding IsNew and IsDirty. If then it is the same as calling Save().
member.returns: A new object containing the saved values.
member.remarks: This overload is designed for use in web applications when implementing the Update method in your data wrapper object.

member.name: M:Csla.SmartDate.DateToString(System.DateTime,System.String)
member.summary: Converts a date value into a text representation.
member.remarks: The date is considered empty if it matches the min value for the Date datatype. If the date is empty, this method returns an empty string. Otherwise it returns the date value formatted based on the FormatString parameter.
member.param: The format string used to format the date into text.
member.returns: Text representation of the date value.

member.name: M:Csla.SmartDate.DateToString(System.DateTime,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts a date value into a text representation.
member.remarks: Whether the date value is considered empty is determined by the EmptyIsMin parameter value. If the date is empty, this method returns an empty string. Otherwise it returns the date value formatted based on the FormatString parameter.
member.param: The format string used to format the date into text.
Indicates whether an empty date is the min or max date value.
member.returns: Text representation of the date value.

Indicates whether an empty date is the min or max date value.
member.returns: Text representation of the date value.

member.name: M:Csla.SmartDate.CompareTo(Csla.SmartDate)
member.summary: Compares one SmartDate to another.

member.returns: A value indicating if the comparison date is less than, equal to or greater than this date.

member.name: M:Csla.SmartDate.CompareTo(System.DateTimeOffset)

member.name: P:Csla.SmartDate.FormatString

member.remarks: The format string should follow the requirements for the .NET System.String.Format statement.
member.value: A format string.

member.name: P:Csla.SmartDate.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the date value.

remarks.para: This property can be used to set the date value by passing a text representation of the date. Any text date representation that can be parsed by the .NET runtime is valid.
When the date value is retrieved via this property, the text is formatted by using the format specified by the property. The default is the short date format (d).

member.name: P:Csla.SmartDate.Date
member.summary: Gets or sets the date value.

member.name: P:Csla.SmartDate.DBValue
member.summary: Gets a database-friendly version of the date value.

remarks.para: If the SmartDate contains an empty date, this returns . Otherwise the actual date value is returned as type Date.
This property is very useful when setting parameter values for a Command object, since it automatically stores null values into the database for empty date values.
When you also use the SafeDataReader and its GetSmartDate method, you can easily read a null value from the database back into a SmartDate object so it remains considered as an empty date value.

member.name: P:Csla.SmartDate.IsEmpty
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this object contains an empty date.

member.name: P:Csla.SmartDate.EmptyIsMin
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether an empty date is the min or max possible date value.
member.remarks: Whether an empty date is considered to be the smallest or largest possible date is only important for comparison operations. This allows you to compare an empty date with a real date and get a meaningful result.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.LinkedList`1.RemoveAll``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary:
Remove all items in another collection from this one, taking multiplicities into account.
Always removes from the front of the list.
The asymptotic running time complexity of this method is O(n+m+v*log(v)), where n is the size of this list, m is the size of the items collection and v is the number of views. The method will temporarily allocate memory of size O(m+v).

member.name: M:Csla.C5.LinkedList`1.Clear
member.summary: Remove all items from this collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.LinkedList`1.RetainAll``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary:
Remove all items not in some other collection from this one, taking multiplicities into account.
The asymptotic running time complexity of this method is O(n+m+v*log(v)), where n is the size of this collection, m is the size of the items collection and v is the number of views. The method will temporarily allocate memory of size O(m+v). The stated complexitiy holds under the assumption that the itemequalityComparer of this list is well-behaved.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.CollectionChangedHandler`1
member.summary:
The type of event raised after an operation on a collection has changed its contents. Normally, a multioperation like AddAll,
will only fire one CollectionChanged event. Any operation that changes the collection must fire CollectionChanged as its last event.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.CollectionClearedHandler`1
member.summary:
The type of event raised after the Clear() operation on a collection.
Note: The Clear() operation will not fire ItemsRemoved events.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ItemsAddedHandler`1
member.summary:
The type of event raised after an item has been added to a collection. The event will be raised at a point of time, where the collection object is in an internally consistent state and before the corresponding CollectionChanged event is raised.
Note: an Update operation will fire an ItemsRemoved and an ItemsAdded event.
Note: When an item is inserted into a list (), both ItemInserted and ItemsAdded events will be fired.
member.param: An object with the item that was added

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ItemsRemovedHandler`1
member.summary:
The type of event raised after an item has been removed from a collection. The event will be raised at a point of time, where the collection object is in an internally consistent state and before the corresponding CollectionChanged event is raised.
Note: The Clear() operation will not fire ItemsRemoved events.
Note: an Update operation will fire an ItemsRemoved and an ItemsAdded event.
Note: When an item is removed from a list by the RemoveAt operation, both an ItemsRemoved and an ItemRemovedAt event will be fired.
member.param: An object with the item that was removed

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ItemInsertedHandler`1
member.summary:
The type of event raised after an item has been inserted into a list by an Insert, InsertFirst or InsertLast operation. The event will be raised at a point of time, where the collection object is in an internally consistent state and before the corresponding CollectionChanged event is raised.
Note: an ItemsAdded event will also be fired.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ItemRemovedAtHandler`1
member.summary:
The type of event raised after an item has been removed from a list by a RemoveAt(int i) operation (or RemoveFirst(), RemoveLast(), Remove() operation). The event will be raised at a point of time, where the collection object is in an internally consistent state and before the corresponding CollectionChanged event is raised.
Note: an ItemRemoved event will also be fired.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.Speed
member.summary: The symbolic characterization of the speed of lookups for a collection. The values may refer to worst-case, amortized and/or expected asymtotic complexity wrt. the collection size.

member.name: F:Csla.C5.Speed.PotentiallyInfinite
member.summary: Counting the collection with the Count property may not return (for a synthetic and potentially infinite collection).

member.name: F:Csla.C5.Speed.Linear
member.summary: Lookup operations like Contains(T item) or the Count property may take time O(n), where n is the size of the collection.

member.name: F:Csla.C5.Speed.Log
member.summary: Lookup operations like Contains(T item) or the Count property takes time O(log n), where n is the size of the collection.

member.name: F:Csla.C5.Speed.Constant
member.summary: Lookup operations like Contains(T item) or the Count property takes time O(1), where n is the size of the collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.HashedLinkedList`1.RemoveAll``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary:
Remove all items in another collection from this one, taking multiplicities into account.
Always removes from the front of the list.
The asymptotic running time complexity of this method is O(n+m+v*log(v)), where n is the size of this list, m is the size of the items collection and v is the number of views. The method will temporarily allocate memory of size O(m+v).

member.name: M:Csla.C5.HashedLinkedList`1.Clear
member.summary: Remove all items from this collection.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.HashedLinkedList`1.RetainAll``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary:
Remove all items not in some other collection from this one, taking multiplicities into account.
The asymptotic running time complexity of this method is O(n+m+v*log(v)), where n is the size of this collection, m is the size of the items collection and v is the number of views. The method will temporarily allocate memory of size O(m+v). The stated complexitiy holds under the assumption that the itemequalityComparer of this list is well-behaved.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.HashedLinkedList`1.ViewHandler.updateViewSizesAndCounts(System.Int32,Csla.C5.HashedLinkedList{`0}.Node)
member.summary:
To be called with n pointing to the right of each node to be removed in a stretch. And at the endsentinel.
Update offset of a view whose left endpoint (has not already been handled and) is n or precedes n. I.e. startsentinel precedes n. Also update the size as a prelude to handling the right endpoint.
Update size of a view not already handled and whose right endpoint precedes n.
member.param: The number of nodes left of n to be removed

member.name: M:Csla.C5.HashedLinkedList`1.ViewHandler.updateSentinels(Csla.C5.HashedLinkedList{`0}.Node,Csla.C5.HashedLinkedList{`0}.Node,Csla.C5.HashedLinkedList{`0}.Node)
member.summary:
To be called with n being the first not-to-be-removed node after a (stretch of) node(s) to be removed.
It will update the startsentinel of views (that have not been handled before and) whose startsentinel precedes n, i.e. is to be deleted.
It will update the endsentinel of views (...) whose endsentinel precedes n, i.e. is to be deleted.
PROBLEM: DOESNT WORK AS ORIGINALLY ADVERTISED. WE MUST DO THIS BEFORE WE ACTUALLY REMOVE THE NODES. WHEN THE NODES HAVE BEEN REMOVED, THE precedes METHOD WILL NOT WORK!

summary.para: The type Act[T] corresponds to System.Action[T] in the .Net Framework class library.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.Fun`2
member.summary:
Delegate type Fun[A1,R] is the type of functions (methods) from A1 to R, used to compute some transformation for a given collection item.
The type Fun[T,U] corresponds to System.Converter[T,U] in the .Net Framework class library, and the type Fun[T,bool] corresponds System.Predicate[T] in the .Net Framework class library.

member.summary: DataBindings_CollectionChanged() is the data bindings collection change event for a control. DataBindings_CollectionChanged() simply updates our binding events hookins correctly based on the collections current state.
member.param: The object that triggered the event.

member.name: M:Csla.Windows.BindingSourceRefresh.Container_ControlAdded(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.ControlEventArgs)
member.summary: Container_ControlAdded() is the control add event for a control's control collection. Container_ControlAdded() simply registers the relevant controller events for the new control as well as registering any required bindings - including those for child controls (based on the controls binding source).
member.param: The object that triggered the event.

member.name: M:Csla.Windows.BindingSourceRefresh.Container_ControlRemoved(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.ControlEventArgs)
member.summary: Container_ControlRemoved() is the control remove event for a control's control collection. Container_ControlRemoved() unregisters all events associated with the control - including those for child controls.
member.param: The object that triggered the event.

member.name: M:Csla.Windows.BindingSourceRefresh.Control_BindingComplete(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.BindingCompleteEventArgs)
member.summary: Control_BindingComplete() is a event driven routine triggered when one of the control's bindings has been completed. Control_BindingComplete() simply validates the result where if the result was a exception then the BindingError event is raised, else if the binding was a successful data source update and we are to re-read the value on changed then the binding value is reread into the control.
member.param: The object that triggered the event.

member.name: M:Csla.Windows.BindingSourceRefresh.System#ComponentModel#ISupportInitialize#EndInit
member.summary: EndInit() is called when the component has finished being initialised. EndInt() sets the initialise flag to false then runs through registering all the different events that the component needs to hook into in Host.

member.name: T:Csla.EditableRootListBase`1
member.summary: This is the base class from which collections of editable root business objects should be derived.
member.typeparam: Type of editable root object to contain within the collection.

remarks.para: Your subclass should implement a factory method and should override or overload DataPortal_Fetch() to implement data retrieval.
Saving (inserts or updates) of items in the collection should be handled through the SaveItem() method on the collection.
Removing an item from the collection through Remove() or RemoveAt() causes immediate deletion of the object, by calling the object's Delete() and Save() methods.

member.name: M:Csla.DataPortal`1.OnCreateCompleted(Csla.DataPortalResult{`0})
member.summary: Raises the event.
member.param: The parameter provided to the event handler.

remarks.para: If your application is running in WPF, this event will be raised on the UI thread automatically.

If your application is running in Windows Forms, this event will be raised on a background thread. If you also set DataPortal.SynchronizationObject to a Windows Forms form or control, then the event will be raised on the UI thread automatically.
In any other environment (such as ASP.NET), this event will be raised on a background thread.

member.name: T:Csla.CommandBase
member.summary: This is the base class from which command objects will be derived.

remarks.para: Command objects allow the execution of arbitrary server-side functionality. Most often, this involves the invocation of a stored procedure in the database, but can involve any other type of stateless, atomic call to the server instead.
To implement a command object, inherit from CommandBase and override the DataPortal_Execute method. In this method you can implement any server-side code as required.

To pass data to/from the server, use instance variables within the command object itself. The command object is instantiated on the client, and is passed by value to the server where the DataPortal_Execute method is invoked. The command object is then returned to the client by value.

member.name: M:Csla.CommandBase.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an instance of the object.

member.name: M:Csla.CommandBase.Initialize
member.summary: Override this method to set up event handlers so user code in a partial class can respond to events raised by generated code.

member.name: M:Csla.CommandBase.DataPortal_Execute
member.summary: Override this method to implement any server-side code that is to be run when the command is executed.

member.name: M:Csla.CommandBase.DataPortal_OnDataPortalInvoke(Csla.DataPortalEventArgs)
member.summary: Called by the server-side DataPortal prior to calling the requested DataPortal_xyz method.
member.param: The DataPortalContext object passed to the DataPortal.

member.summary: Called by the server-side DataPortal after calling the requested DataPortal_xyz method.
member.param: The DataPortalContext object passed to the DataPortal.

member.name: M:Csla.CommandBase.DataPortal_OnDataPortalException(Csla.DataPortalEventArgs,System.Exception)
member.summary: Called by the server-side DataPortal if an exception occurs during server-side processing.
member.param: The DataPortalContext object passed to the DataPortal.

member.summary: A default item comparer for an item type that is either generic (IComparable<T>) or ordinarily (System.IComparable) comparable.

member.name: P:Csla.C5.Comparer`1.Default
member.summary:
Create a default comparer.
The IComparer[T] object is constructed when this class is initialised, i.e. its static constructors called. Thus, the property will be the same object for the duration of an invocation of the runtime, but a value serialized in another invocation and deserialized here will not be the same object.
member.exception: If T is not comparable
member.value: The comparer

member.name: T:Csla.ApplicationContext
member.summary: Provides consistent context information between the client and server DataPortal objects.

member.name: M:Csla.ApplicationContext.Clear
member.summary: Clears all context collections.

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.User
member.summary: Get or set the current object representing the user's identity.
member.remarks: This is discussed in Chapter 5. When running under IIS the HttpContext.Current.User value is used, otherwise the current Thread.CurrentPrincipal value is used.

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.LocalContext
member.summary: Returns the application-specific context data that is local to the current AppDomain.

remarks.para: The return value is a HybridDictionary. If one does not already exist, and empty one is created and returned.
Note that data in this context is NOT transferred to and from the client and server.

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.ClientContext
member.summary: Returns the application-specific context data provided by the client.

remarks.para: The return value is a HybridDictionary. If one does not already exist, and empty one is created and returned.
Note that data in this context is transferred from the client to the server. No data is transferred from the server to the client.

This property is thread safe in a Windows client setting and on an application server. It is not guaranteed to be thread safe within the context of an ASP.NET client setting (i.e. in your ASP.NET UI).

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.GlobalContext
member.summary: Returns the application-specific context data shared on both client and server.

remarks.para: The return value is a HybridDictionary. If one does not already exist, and empty one is created and returned.
Note that data in this context is transferred to and from the client and server. Any objects or data in this context will be transferred bi-directionally across the network.

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.AuthenticationType
member.summary: Returns the authentication type being used by the CSLA .NET framework.
member.remarks: This value is read from the application configuration file with the key value "CslaAuthentication". The value "Windows" indicates CSLA .NET should use Windows integrated (or AD) security. Any other value indicates the use of custom security derived from BusinessPrincipalBase.

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.DataPortalProxy
member.summary: Gets or sets the full type name (or 'Local') of the data portal proxy object to be used when communicating with the data portal server.
member.value: Fully qualified assembly/type name of the proxy class or 'Local'.

remarks.para: If this value is empty or null, a new value is read from the application configuration file with the key value "CslaDataPortalProxy".
The proxy class must implement Csla.Server.IDataPortalServer.
The value "Local" is a shortcut to running the DataPortal "server" in the client process.

Other built-in values include:
Csla,Csla.DataPortalClient.RemotingProxy Use .NET Remoting to communicate with the server
Csla,Csla.DataPortalClient.EnterpriseServicesProxy Use Enterprise Services (DCOM) to communicate with the server
Csla,Csla.DataPortalClient.WebServicesProxy Use Web Services (asmx) to communicate with the server
Each proxy type does require that the DataPortal server be hosted using the appropriate technology. For instance, Web Services and Remoting should be hosted in IIS, while Enterprise Services must be hosted in COM+.

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.DataPortalUrl
member.summary: Returns the URL for the DataPortal server.
member.remarks: This value is read from the application configuration file with the key value "CslaDataPortalUrl".

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.IsInRoleProvider
member.summary: Gets a fully qualified name for a class that implements the IsInRole() behavior used for authorization.
member.returns: Returns a value in the form "Namespace.Class, Assembly".
member.remarks: The default is to use a simple IsInRole() call against the current principal. If another fylly qualified class name and method is supplied it must conform to the IsInRoleProvider delegate. See also IsInRoleProviderName that must give the methodname that implements the IsInRole method.

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.IsInRoleMethodName
member.summary: Gets the method name that implements the IsInRole() behavior used for authorization.
member.returns: Returns a value in the form "MethodName".

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.AutoCloneOnUpdate
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether objects should be automatically cloned by the data portal Update() method when using a local data portal configuration.

member.name: P:Csla.ApplicationContext.SerializationFormatter

remarks.para:
If you use the DataContract and DataMember attributes to specify how your objects should be serialized then you must change this setting to use the
NetDataContractSerializer option. The default is to use the standard Microsoft .NET .
This setting does not affect the serialization formatters used by the various data portal channels.

If you are using the Remoting, Web Services or Enterprise Services technologies, they will use the BinaryFormatter regardless of this setting, and will fail to work if you attempt to use the DataContract and DataMember attributes when building your business objects.

If you want to use DataContract and DataMember, and you want a remote data portal server, you must use the WCF data portal channel, or create your own custom channel that uses the
NetDataContractSerializer provided as part of WCF.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.TreeBag`1
member.summary:
An implementation of Red-Black trees as an indexed, sorted collection with bag semantics, cf. CLRS. ( for an implementation with set semantics).
The comparer (sorting order) may be either natural, because the item type is comparable (generic: or non-generic: System.IComparable) or it can be external and supplied by the user in the constructor.
Each distinct item is only kept in one place in the tree - together with the number of times it is a member of the bag. Thus, if two items that are equal according

member.name: M:Csla.BusinessListBase`2.BeginEdit
member.summary: Starts a nested edit on the object.

remarks.para: When this method is called the object takes a snapshot of its current state (the values of its variables). This snapshot can be restored by calling or committed by calling .

This is a nested operation. Each call to BeginEdit adds a new snapshot of the object's state to a stack. You should ensure that for each call to BeginEdit there is a corresponding call to either CancelEdit or ApplyEdit to remove that snapshot from the stack.
See Chapters 2 and 3 for details on n-level undo and state stacking.
This method triggers the copying of all child object states.

member.name: M:Csla.BusinessListBase`2.CancelEdit
member.summary: Cancels the current edit process, restoring the object's state to its previous values.
member.remarks:
Calling this method causes the most recently taken snapshot of the object's state to be restored. This resets the object's values to the point of the last call.
This method triggers an undo in all child objects.

member.name: M:Csla.BusinessListBase`2.ApplyEdit
member.summary: Commits the current edit process.
member.remarks:
Calling this method causes the most recently taken snapshot of the object's state to be discarded, thus committing any changes made to the object's state since the last call.
This method triggers an in all child objects.

member.name: M:Csla.BusinessListBase`2.MarkAsChild
member.summary: Marks the object as being a child object.

remarks.para: By default all business objects are 'parent' objects. This means that they can be directly retrieved and updated into the database.
We often also need child objects. These are objects which are contained within other objects. For instance, a parent Invoice object will contain child LineItem objects.
To create a child object, the MarkAsChild method must be called as the object is created. Please see Chapter 7 for details on the use of the MarkAsChild method.

member.name: M:Csla.BusinessListBase`2.Save
member.summary: Saves the object to the database.

remarks.para: Calling this method starts the save operation, causing the all child objects to be inserted, updated or deleted within the database based on the each object's current state.

All this is contingent on . If this value is , no data operation occurs. It is also contingent on . If this value is an exception will be thrown to indicate that the UI attempted to save an invalid object.

It is important to note that this method returns a new version of the business collection that contains any data updated during the save operation. You MUST update all object references to use this new version of the business collection in order to have access to the correct object data.

You can override this method to add your own custom behaviors to the save operation. For instance, you may add some security checks to make sure the user can save the object. If all security checks pass, you would then invoke the base Save method via MyBase.Save().

member.returns: A new object containing the saved values.

member.name: T:Csla.Core.ObjectCloner
member.summary: This class provides an implementation of a deep clone of a complete object graph. Objects are copied at the field level.

member.name: M:Csla.Core.ObjectCloner.Clone(System.Object)
member.summary: Clones an object.
member.remarks:
The object to be cloned must be serializable.
The serialization is performed using the formatter specified in the application's configuration file using the CslaSerializationFormatter key.
The default is to use the
. You may also choose to use the Microsoft .NET 3.0
NetDataContractSerializer provided as part of WCF.

member.summary: Cancels changes to the business object, returning it to its previous state.
member.remarks: This metod does nothing unless ManageLifetime is set to true and the object supports n-level undo.

member.name: M:Csla.Wpf.CslaDataProvider.Save
member.summary: Accepts changes to the business object, and commits them by calling the object's Save() method.

remarks.para: This method does nothing unless the object implements Csla.Core.ISavable.
If the object implements IClonable, it will be cloned, and the clone will be saved.
If the object supports n-level undo and ManageLifetime is true, then this method will automatically call ApplyEdit() and BeginEdit() appropriately.

member.name: T:Csla.TransactionalAttribute
member.summary: Marks a DataPortal_XYZ method to run within the specified transactional context.

remarks.para: Each business object method may be marked with this attribute to indicate which type of transactional technology should be used by the server-side DataPortal. The possible options are listed in the TransactionalTypes enum.
If the Transactional attribute is not applied to a DataPortal_XYZ method then the Manual option is assumed.
If the Transactional attribute is applied with no explicit choice for transactionType then the EnterpriseServices option is assumed.
Both the EnterpriseServices and TransactionScope options provide 2-phase distributed transactional support.

member.name: M:Csla.TransactionalAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Marks a method to run within a COM+ transactional context.

member.name: M:Csla.TransactionalAttribute.#ctor(Csla.TransactionalTypes)

member.param: Specifies the transactional context within which the method should run.

member.summary: Gets the type of transaction requested by the business object method.

member.summary: Utility class for building default generic equalityComparers.

member.name: P:Csla.C5.EqualityComparer`1.Default
member.summary:
A default generic equality comparer for type T. The procedure is as follows:
If T is a primitive type (char, sbyte, byte, short, ushort, int, uint, float, double, decimal), the equalityComparer will be a standard equalityComparer for that type
If the actual generic argument T implements the generic interface for some value W of its generic parameter T, the equalityComparer will be
If the actual generic argument T implements for some value W of its generic parameter T, the equalityComparer will be
If T is a type implementing , the equalityComparer will be
If T is a type not implementing , the equalityComparer will be
The object is constructed when this class is initialised, i.e. its static constructors called. Thus, the property will be the same object for the duration of an invocation of the runtime, but a value serialized in another invocation and deserialized here will not be the same object.

member.summary: A default item equalityComparer calling through to the GetHashCode and Equals methods inherited from System.Object.

member.name: M:Csla.C5.NaturalEqualityComparer`1.GetHashCode(`0)
member.summary: Get the hash code with respect to this item equalityComparer

member.name: M:Csla.C5.NaturalEqualityComparer`1.Equals(`0,`0)
member.summary: Check if two items are equal with respect to this item equalityComparer

member.name: T:Csla.C5.EquatableEqualityComparer`1
member.summary:
A default equality comparer for a type T that implements System.IEquatable.
The equality comparer forwards calls to GetHashCode and Equals to the IEquatable methods on T, so Equals(T) is called, not Equals(object). This will save boxing abd unboxing if T is a value type and in general saves a runtime type check.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ReferenceEqualityComparer`1
member.summary: A equalityComparer for a reference type that uses reference equality for equality and the hash code from object as hash code.
member.typeparam: The item type. Must be a reference type.

member.name: T:Csla.C5.ComparerZeroHashCodeEqualityComparer`1
member.summary:
An equalityComparer compatible with a given comparer. All hash codes are 0, meaning that anything based on hash codes will be quite inefficient.
Note: this will give a new EqualityComparer each time created!

member.name: M:Csla.C5.ComparerZeroHashCodeEqualityComparer`1.Equals(`0,`0)
member.summary: Equality of two items as defined by the comparer.
